column1: Na túto myšlienku ma prvýkrát priviedol tohtoročný blog od Dereka K. Millera, vedeckého a technologického novinára, ktorý zomrel na rakovinu.
column2: What first got me thinking about this was a blog post authored earlier this year by Derek K. Miller , who was a science and technology journalist who died of cancer .

column1: A Miller zadal svojej rodine a známym, aby napísali príspevok, ktorý bol publikovaný krátko potom ako zomrel.
column2: And what Miller did was have his family and friends write a post that went out shortly after he died .

column1: Toto napísal v úvode.

column1: Dopredu som požiadal, aby keď sa moje telo konečne zbaví týrania rakovinou, aby moja rodina a priatelia publikovali túto pripravenú správu - ako prvú časť procesu pretvorenia tejto aktívnej stránky na archív." Ako u novinára, Millerov archív bol asi písaný lepšie a spravovaný pozornejšie ako iné, ale pointa je, že dnes my všetci tvoríme archív, ktorý je niečím úplne iným, ako čokoľvek, čo bolo vytvorené hocktorou predošlou generáciou.
column2: In advance , I asked that once my body finally shut down from the punishments of my cancer , then my family and friends publish this prepared message I wrote — the first part of the process of turning this from an active website to an archive .  " Now , while as a journalist , Miller 's archive may have been better written and more carefully curated than most , the fact of the matter is that all of us today are creating an archive that 's something completely different than anything that 's been created by any previous generation . "

column1: Zamyslite sa nad pár štatistikami.

column2: So when you think about your parents or your grandparents , at best they may have created some photos or home videos , or a diary that lives in a box somewhere .

column2: But today we 're all creating this incredibly rich digital archive that 's going to live in the cloud indefinitely , years after we 're gone .

column2: I think as machines ' ability to understand human language and process vast amounts of data continues to improve , it 's going to become possible to analyze an entire life 's worth of content — the Tweets , the photos , the videos , the blog posts — that we 're producing in such massive numbers .

column1: A myslím, že keď sa to stane, bude možné pre naše digitálne 'persóny' pokračovať v interakcii s reálnym svetom dlho po tom, ako odídeme, a to vďaka obrovskému množstvu obsahu, ktorí tvoríme a schopnosťou technológií to všetko pochopiť.
column2: And I think as that happens , it 's going to become possible for our digital personas to continue to interact in the real world long after we 're gone thanks to the vastness of the amount of content we 're creating and technology 's ability to make sense of it all .

column2: What if we were able to use that same type of technology to beam a representation of our loved ones into our living rooms — interacting in a very lifelike way based on all the content they created while they were alive ?

column2: Now in closing , I think what we all need to be thinking about is if we want that to become our reality — and if so , what it means for a definition of life and everything that comes after it .

column2: Since we are still realizing these works , we are largely working within the realm of intuition and mystery , still .

column1: Takže prvé dielo sa volá Imperial Monochromes.
column2: So the first work is called the Imperial Monochromes .

column1: Nič netušiaci divák vstúpi do miestnosti a všimne si tieto panely, ako neusporiadanú kompozíciu na stene.
column2: A viewer sort of unsuspectingly walks into the room , and catches a glimpse of these panels in a messy composition on the wall .

column1: V priebehu niekoľkých sekúnd ako keby si panely všimli prítomnosť diváka, vyzerá to, že spanikárili a zoskupili sa striktne symetricky.
column2: Within seconds , as if the panels have noticed the presence of the viewer , they appear to panic and sort of get into a strict symmetry .

column1: (Smiech) Toto je nákres dvoch stavov.
column2: ( Laughter ) So this is the sketch of the two states .

column1: Prvým je úplným chaos. Druhým úplný poriadok.
column2: One is total chaos . The other is absolute order .

column1: A nás zaujímalo, ako málo stačí na prechod z jedného stavu do druhého.
column2: And we were interested in seeing how little change it takes to move from one state to the other state .

column1: Toto nám pripomenulo aj dve  veľmi odlišné umelecké tradície.
column2: This also reminded us of two very different pictorial traditions .

column1: Prvou sú oltárne tablety z 15. storočia, druhá pochádza asi spred 100 rokov. Malevichove abstraktné kompozície.
column2: One is the altar tablets of the 15th century , and the other is about 100 years ago , Malevich 's abstract compositions .

column1: Takže vám ukážem video.
column2: So I 'm just going to take you to a video .

column1: Aby ste mali predstavu o skutočných rozmeroch, najväčší z panelov je približne dva metre vysoký.
column2: To give you a sense of scale , the largest panel is about two meters high .

column1: Približne toľkoto. A najmenší je veľkosti A4.
column2: That 's about this much . And the smallest one is an A4 .

column1: Takže divák vojde do miesnosti, a hneď sú v pozore.
column2: So a viewer enters the space , and they snap to attention .

column1: Po chvíli, ak divák ostane v miestnosti, panely sa stanú voči jeho prítomnosti v miestnosti imúnnymi, a znova získajú autonómiu, kým znova nepocítia prítomnosť alebo pohyb, a potom sa znova postavia do pozoru.
column2: And after a while , if the viewer continues to remain in the space , the panels will sort of become immune to the presence of the viewer and become lax and autonomous again , until they sort of sense a presence in the room or a movement , when they will again snap to attention .

column1: (Smiech) Tu to teda vyzerá, že divák akoby spôsoboval poriadok medzi panelmi, ale mohlo by to byť aj naopak. Možno sú panely tak zvyknuté na svoje vopred určené správanie, že diváka nútia do úlohy tyrana.
column2: ( Laughter ) So here it appears as if it 's the viewer that 's sort of instigating the sense of order among the panels , but it could also be the other way around , that the panels are so stuck within their preconditioned behaviors that they sort of thrust the viewer with the role of a tyrant .

column1: Toto ma teda privádza k tichšiemu, menšiemu dielu menom Handheld.
column2: So this brings me to a quieter , small work called Handheld .

column1: Divák vidí kúsok papiera umiestneného na stene na opačnej strane miestnosti, ale keď sa priblíži, vidí, že je to prázdny list A4 alebo prázdny listový papier, ktorý na každej strane držia dve malé ruky vyrezané z malého kúska dreva do najmenších detailov a s vysokou pozornosťou.
column2: The viewer sees a piece of paper that 's mounted on the far end of the wall , but when you go closer , you see that it 's a blank A4 , or a letter-sized piece of paper , that 's held on either side by two small hands that appear to be carved with a great deal of attention and care from a small block of wood .

column1: Divák vidí aj to, že sa celá táto socha veľmi pomaly pohybuje, akoby sa tieto dve ruky snažili držať papier na mieste veľmi dlhý čas, a celkom sa im to nedarilo.
column2: The viewer also sees that this entire sculpture is sort of moving very slightly , as if these two hands are trying to hold the paper very still for a long period of time , and somehow are not managing to .

column1: Takže táto nestabilita pohybu veľmi výrazne pripomína nestabilnosť obrazov, ktoré vidíme cez ručnú kameru.
column2: So this instability in the movement very closely resembles the unsteady nature of images seen through a handheld camera .

column1: Tu vám teda ukážem dva zábery.
column2: So here I 'm going to show you two tandem clips .

column1: Jeden z pevne umiestnenej kamery, a druhý z ručnej kamery.
column2: One is through a still camera and the other is through a handheld camera .

column1: A hneď vidíte, ako nestálosť tohto videa naznačuje prítomnosť pozorovateľa a subjektívneho uhla pohľadu.
column2: And you immediately see how the unsteady nature of the video suggests the presence of an observer and a subjective point of view .

column1: Takže sme jednoducho odstránili kameru a presunuli tento pohyb na panel.
column2: So we 've just removed the camera and transferred that movement onto the panel .

column1: Takže tu je video.
column2: So here 's a video .

column1: Musíme si predstaviť druhú ruku. Ešte tam nie je.

column2: But to us , we 're sort of trying to evoke a self-effacing gesture , as if there 's a little person with outstretched arms behind this enormous piece of paper .

column1: Toto je prirovnaním k snahe slúžiť pozorovateľovi a veľmi delikátne tento kus papiera pred nimi prezentovať pozorovateľovi.
column2: That sort of likens it to the amount of strain to be at the service of the observer and present this piece of paper very delicately to the viewer in front of them .

column1: Ďalším dielom je Decoy.
column2: The next work is Decoy .

column2: This is a cardboard model , so the object is about as tall as I am .

column2: It has a rounded body , two arms , and a very tall , head-like antenna , and its sole purpose is to attract attention towards itself .

column1: Takže keď popri ňom prejde divák, začne sa kývať zo strany na stranu a hýbe rukami, stále rýchlejšie a rýchlejšie, čím viac sa divák približuje.
column2: So when a viewer passes by , it sort of tilts from side to side , and moves its arms more and more frantically as the person gets closer .

column1: Takže toto je prvý test.
column2: So here is the first test scenario .

column1: Vidíte dva pohyby spolu, a celý predmet sa snaží do vyjadrenia zúfalstva zapojiť celú svoju bytosť.
column2: You see the two movements integrated , and the object seems to be employing its entire being in this expression of desperation .

column1: Pointou ale je, že keď získa pozornosť diváka, stratí o ňu záujem o začne hľadať niekoho ďalšieho.
column2: But the idea is that once it 's got the person 's attention , it 's no longer interested , and it looks for the next person whose attention to get .

column1: (Smiech) Toto je dokončené telo Decoy.

column1: Vyzerá masovo vyrobený, akoby z továrne, ako napríklad vysávače alebo práčky.
column2: It appears to be mass-manufactured like it came out of a factory like vacuum cleaners and washing machines .

column1: Pretože vždy pracujeme z veľmi osobného priestoru, páči sa nám, ako táto spotrebná estetika do istej miery depersonalizuje celé dielo a poskytuje nám istý odstup od jeho výzoru.
column2: Because we are always working from a very personal space , we like how this consumer aesthetic sort of depersonalizes the object and gives us a bit of distance in its appearance , at least .

column1: Toto je teda istá zlovestná bytosť, ktorá sa snaží odpútať vás od vecí, ktoré vašu pozornosť naozaj potrebujú, ale môže byť aj bytosťou, ktorá veľmi potrebuje pomoc.
column2: And so to us this is a kind of sinister being which is trying to distract you from the things that actually need your attention , but it could also be a figure that needs a lot of help .

column1: Ďalším dielom je predmet, ktorý je aj hudobným nástrojom.
column2: The next work is an object , that 's also a kind of sound instrument .

column1: V tvare amfiteátra, ktorý je prispôsobený veľkosti publika z pohľadu niekoho na javisku.
column2: In the shape of an amphitheater that 's scaled to the size of an audience as perceived from somebody from the stage .

column1: Takže odtiaľ, kde stojím, každý z vás vyzerá takto veľký, a celé publikum zaberá celé moje zrakové pole.
column2: So from where I 'm standing , each of you appears to be this big , and the audience sort of takes the entire field of my vision .

column1: Sú vybavené na to, aby mohli z vlastnej vôle tlieskať.
column2: They 're mechanically enabled to clap of their own free will .

column1: Toto znamená, že každý z nich sa môže rozhodnúť, kedy chce tlieskať, ako silno, a ako dlho, ako chcú byť ovplyvňovaný inými alebo ich ovplyvňovať, a či sa chcú podieľať na inovácii.
column2: This means that each of them can decide if and when they want to clap , how hard , for how long , how they want to be influenced by those around them or influence others , and if they want to contribute to innovation .

column1: Takže keď divák vstúpi pred publikum, dostane odozvu.
column2: So when the viewer steps in front of the audience , there will be a response .

column1: Môže to byť slabý alebo silný potlesk, a potom sa nič nestane, až kým divák neopustí javisko, a publikum znova zareaguje.
column2: It could be a few claps or a strong applause , and then nothing happens until the viewer leaves the stage , and again the audience will respond .

column2: It could be anything from a few feeble claps from members in the audience , or it could be a very loud ovation .

column1: Pre nás to znamená, že sa pozeráme na publikum ako samostatný objekt, ako vlastný organizmus, ktorý má aj takmer hudobné vlastnosti, ako hudobný nástroj.
column2: So to us , I think we 're really looking at an audience as its own object or its own organism that 's also got a sort of musical-like quality to it , an instrument .

column2: So the viewer can play it by eliciting quite complex and varied , nuanced musical or sound patterns , but cannot really provoke the audience into any particular kind of response .

column1: Dielo teda obsahuje istú mieru hodnotenia, nepredvídateľnosti a nepohodlia.
column2: So there 's a sense of judgment and capriciousness and uneasiness involved .

column1: Istým spôsobom pripomína aj pascu.

column2: So here 's a small visual animation , as if the two sides of the brain are sort of clashing against each other to kind of make sense of the duality and the tension .

column1: A tu je prototyp.

column2: We get information in the mail , the regular postal mail , encrypted or not , vet it like a regular news organization , format it — which is sometimes something that 's quite hard to do , when you 're talking about giant databases of information — release it to the public and then defend ourselves against the inevitable legal and political attacks .
